title: John Gillis (historian)
text:
John R. Gillis (; born 1939, died 2021) was an American historian. He was Professor Emeritus of <a href="History">History</a> at <a href="Rutgers%20University">Rutgers University</a>. 
Education.
Gillis received his <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">B.A.</a> from <a href="Amherst%20College">Amherst College</a> and a <a href="Ph.D.">Ph.D.</a> from <a href="Stanford%20University">Stanford University</a> under the direction of <a href="Gordon%20A.%20Craig">Gordon A. Craig</a>.
Personal.
Gillis was married to Christina Mardsen Gillis, author of Writing on Stone: Scenes from a Maine Island Life.
Academic work.
Gillis' early work was largely in <a href="Social%20history">social</a> and <a href="cultural%20history">cultural history</a>. He began as a <a href="History%20of%20Germany">German</a> historian, moved to <a href="History%20of%20the%20British%20Isles">British</a> history, and then to age relations, marriage, memory, and the cultures of European and American family life. He later moved on to global history, with an emphasis on cultural geography and environmental history.
In 2004 he published "Islands of the Mind," on the role played by islands in the economic, political, and social dimensions of Atlantic world and the way the myths, images, and narratives of islands function for mainland cultures.
Gillis subsequently began studying the history and geography of coasts and coastal peoples. In his 2012 book "The Human Shore: Seacoasts in History," he begins with the first humans to approach the shore, tracing coastal migrations around the world, and discussing the ways that coasts and coastal people have figured in <a href="globalization">globalization</a> over several centuries. The book concludes with an assessment of the current crisis of coasts when faced with the effects of climate change, treating coasts as an <a href="ecotone">ecotone</a> that encompasses both land and water. The book was published by the <a href="University%20of%20Chicago%20Press">University of Chicago Press</a>.
Gillis retired from Rutgers University in 2005 and since that time lived in <a href="Berkeley%2C%20California">Berkeley, California</a> while spending summers on <a href="Great%20Gott%20Island">Great Gott Island</a>, off <a href="Acadia%20National%20Park">Acadia National Park</a> in <a href="Maine">Maine</a>. There he was involved with the Island Institute, in <a href="Rockland%2C%20Maine">Rockland, Maine</a>. He published six books and edited four others.

Gillis was an active and highly respected doctoral adviser, steering eleven students to their PhDs at Rutgers. These former advisees include: 
Professional affiliation.
Gillis was a current member of the editorial boards of the <a href="Journal%20of%20Family%20History">Journal of Family History</a> and , and a past editorial board member of the <a href="Journal%20of%20Modern%20History">Journal of Modern History</a>. He taught at <a href="Princeton%20University">Princeton University</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20California%20at%20Berkeley">University of California at Berkeley</a>, was a visiting fellow of <a href="St.%20Antony%27s%20College">St. Antony's College</a>, Oxford, and was a Life Member of <a href="Clare%20Hall%2C%20Cambridge">Clare Hall</a>, <a href="Cambridge%20University">Cambridge University</a>.
He was a member of the <a href="American%20Association%20of%20University%20Professors">American Association of University Professors</a>, the <a href="American%20Historical%20Association">American Historical Association</a>, and the <a href="World%20History%20Association">World History Association</a>. He was the former national co-chair of the Council on Contemporary Families.
